I like that idea.  Except, instead of "hintLayer", how about if we make it
something more explicit like "distance-from-input"; i.e., the shortest path
between that neuron and in the input layer?

Derek and I also talked about doing something more complex than shortest
path.  Every neuron is going to have (potentially) many many paths of
different lengths between it and the input and output layers, even with
recurrent connections disregarded.  If you use shortest distance, all it
takes is one connection to the input layer to "yank" that neuron back to the
first hidden layer, even though it may have many more connections with
longer paths that, overall, would more logically place it in a layer closer
to the output.

Also, if what we really want is something readable, even if the network
logically lays out as a 3 layer network with 2000 nodes in the hidden layer,
a layout that breaks that layer into multiple layers probably would be more
readable.

What if we calculated a ratio of average distance to the output and input
layers from each neuron?  For example, let's say a neuron has:

- several paths between it and the input layer whose average distance is 3
connections
- several paths between it and the output layer whose average distance is 2
connections

It's "layer-placement-factor" (or whatever we want to call it) would be 0.6;
i.e., it should be placed in a layer about 3/5 of the way between the input
and output layers.  Then, whatever's doing the graphical layout can sort all
the neurons in ascending order of this factor and place them in layers
accordingly.

Maybe that's all overkill, but it seems like it would give whatever utility
is doing the layout the information it needs to determine layers without
forcing neurons into a specific layer.

- Philip
